dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: HAHAHAHA! Oh my gosh, are you serious?! Yeah, Host_A, I'm, uh, completely serious. That's the news from New York Life's survey.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: H A H A H A H A! Oh my gosh, are you serious?! Yeah, Host_A, I'm, uh, completely serious. That's the news from New York Life's survey.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats the sobering news from New York Lifes 2018 Life Insurance Gap Survey.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Butâ€¦ a $352,000 shortfall for millennials? Like, what even is that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But... a three hundred fifty two thousand dollars shortfall for millennials? Like, what even is that?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, um, they say they need around $450,000 in coverage, but only have like a hundred thousand in place. It's a huge gap.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, um, they say they need around four hundred fifty thousand dollars in coverage, but only have like a hundred thousand in place. It's a huge gap.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Millennials with life insurance have an average of $100,000 in life insurance protection in place, enough to cover one fifth (22%) of their self-reported coverage needs of $452,000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's just... I mean, don't people care about their families? Or, uh, their loved ones?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's just... I mean, don't people care about their families? Or, uh, their loved ones?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: They do, but it's more of a prioritization issue. It's, like, competing with the big screen TV, that daily coffee, student loans.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They do, but it's more of a prioritization issue. It's, like, competing with the big screen T V, that daily coffee, student loans.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The concept of taking care of their families and loved ones is in competition with the big screen tv, car and even that daily cup of coffee. Not to mention their student loan debtand the desire to save for their childrens education.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Ugh, student loans. Yeah, I get that. But 78% shortfall? That's just, like, wild. Is it just millennials?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ugh, student loans. Yeah, I get that. But seventy eight percent shortfall? That's just, like, wild. Is it just millennials?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Millennialsanyone born between 1981 and 1996, so ages 22 to 37 this yearreport a 78% shortfall in life insurance coverage, according to the survey.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, but they're, uh, definitely the highest. Gen X is at 48%, and boomers are around 37% according to the survey.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, but they're, uh, definitely the highest. Gen X is at forty eight percent, and boomers are around thirty seven percent according to the survey.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By contrast, Gen Xers, born between 1965 and 1980, so 38 to 53 this yearreport a 48% coverage shortfall. ... Baby Boomers say they have $190,000 of coverage but need $300,000a 37% shortfall.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. Okay. So, uh, when do people even think about getting this stuff?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. Okay. So, uh, when do people even think about getting this stuff?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The article suggests it's usually, um, when they buy a home or, uh, have kids. Those are the big triggers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The article suggests it's usually, um, when they buy a home or, uh, have kids. Those are the big triggers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Buying a home and having kids are the two big things that prompt people to get coverage.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that makes sense. But what about, like, insurance through work? Isn't that enough?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that makes sense. But what about, like, insurance through work? Isn't that enough?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Often not, actually. That policy might only pay out, uh, one or two years' salary, and it ends if you leave the job.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Often not, actually. That policy might only pay out, uh, one or two years' salary, and it ends if you leave the job.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If you have life insurance coverage at work, keep in mind that that policy might pay only one- or two-years salary, and it will likely end if you leave your job.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, what? So that's, like, basically nothing? So what should you even look for, then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what? So that's, like, basically nothing? So what should you even look for, then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The article really highlights term life. It's, uh, surprisingly cheap. Like, a healthy 35-year-old can get $500,000 in coverage for, um, like $250 a year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The article really highlights term life. It's, uh, surprisingly cheap. Like, a healthy thirty five-year-old can get five hundred thousand dollars in coverage for, um, like two hundred fifty dollars a year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For a healthy 35-year-old male, it would cost about $250 a year for a 20-year level term policy with a $500,000 death benefit, according to Term4sale.com, where you can run your own numbers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No way! $250 a year?! That's, like, less than my streaming services!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No way! two hundred fifty dollars a year?! That's, like, less than my streaming services!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? And, um, buying younger locks in a better rate. You just gotta shop around, check the company.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? And, um, buying younger locks in a better rate. You just gotta shop around, check the company.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Buying younger lets you lock in a lower level premium. ... Premiums vary greatly for the same product from different insurers, so shop around. And make sure you assess the financial strength of the insurance company before you buy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. Okay. So it's not, like, some huge, unattainable thing. I guess I have, uh, some calls to make.
